<form onsubmit="event.preventDefault(); checkAnswer('module2_mcq_q12')" data-correct-answer="B">
<strong style="display: block;">
An investor is comparing two assets:  
- Asset X: Expected return of 14% with standard deviation of 20%.  
- Asset Y: Expected return of 6% with standard deviation of 2% (risk-free Treasury bill).  

If the investor allocates 25% of the portfolio to Asset X and 75% to Asset Y, what is the expected portfolio return?
</strong>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q12" value="A"> A. 6.5%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q12" value="B"> B. 8.0%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q12" value="C"> C. 9.5%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q12" value="D"> D. 10.0%</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="module2_mcq_q12" value="E"> E. 11.5%</label><br>
</form>
<div id="feedback-module2_mcq_q12" class="feedback" data-status="" style="display:none;">
✅ Correct: B. Portfolio expected return = 0.25×14% + 0.75×6% = **8.0%**.  
This illustrates how combining risky and risk-free assets changes expected performance.
</div>
